Исаева Мира – лидер данной группы. Ей сорок три года. Мира – мать троих детей. Старшей дочери восемнадцать лет, среднему сыну четырнадцать, а младшей дочери всего семь. Мира выбрала себе изначально довольно традиционное занятие – учитель в начальных классах. Однако в условиях современной жизни, когда бюджетников не очень жалуют зарплатами, встал вопрос о том, чтобы находить дополнительный источник заработков. Так муж Миры стал фермером, а Мира, по мере возможности стала помогать мужу. Привыкнуть к новому роду деятельности довольно нелегкое дело. Однако, Мира имела твёрдое намерение по улучшению жизни своей семьи и ей пришлось осваивать новое занятие. Сейчас они с мужем уже не нуждаются в чьей – либо консультации по поводу того, как надо сажать  и что, как следует выращивать. Мира обратилась за этим кредитом, так как сейчас им надо закупить солярки по оптовой цене. Они очень надеются получить этот кредит и купить солярки.

Партнёры Миры по группе:

Джапаеву Алтынбеку двадцать пять. Он уже женат и у него сын, которому исполнился всего месяц. А также с ним живёт его сестра, которой Алтынбек помогает. Чтобы прокормить семью, Алтынбек работает учителем информатики. Помимо этого, Алтынбек активно занимается сельским хозяйством. Алтынбек нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить солярки. 

Табалдиевой Гульзат сорок три года. Гульзат – вдова и сама восритывает троих детей. Для того, чтобы прокормить семью, она занимается сельским хозяйством. Сейчас для Гульзат стоит приоритетная задача – ей необходимо закупить солярки, но средств у неё не имеется. Она обратилась именно за этим кредитом, так как очень верит, что у неё всё получится. 

Иманкожаевой Талайкул сорок восемь лет. Талайкуль – вдова, и мать четверых детей. Она сама обучила детей и до сих пор их со всем усердием поддерживает. Талайкул занимается земледелием. Она выращивает различные овощи и сейчас очень надеется на получение этого кредита, так как он позволит ей закупить солярки. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
All of us experience moments in our lives when we cease enjoying our activities and start detesting everything surrounding us. Only strong people are capable of overcoming such psychological troubles and of making themselves focus on work while hoping for a change to the patter. Reading this group’s story, it becomes clear that many such strong people may be found next to us every day. Mira I. is this group’s leader. She is 43 years old. She is the mother of three children. The oldest daughter is 18 years old; the middle child, a son, is 14; and the youngest daughter is only seven. Initially, Mira had chosen a fairly traditional profession for herself—grammar school teacher. Yet in today’s conditions when civil servants are hardly getting paid, it has become necessary for her to find an additional source of income. This is how Mira’s husband became a farmer, and Mira has been helping her husband as much as she could. Getting used to a new professional occupation is not easy. Yet Mira was firmly set on improving her family’s life conditions and she had no choice but to learn a new trade. By now she and her husband no longer need to consult others about the right steps to follow when planting and growing their crops. Mira has requested this loan as she and her husband need to buy diesel fuel at wholesale prices. They are really hoping to be able to obtain this loan and to purchase fuel. Other members of Mira’s group: Altynbek Z. is 25 years old. He is already married and has a son, born just a month ago. Altynbek’s sister, to whom he helps with expenses, also lives with the family. In order to support his family, Altynbek works as an informatics teacher. In addition, he is actively working in agriculture. He needs a loan to purchase diesel fuel. Gulzat T. is 43 years old. She is a widow, raising three children on her own. She does agricultural work in order to support her family. Right now she has a pressing need for fuel, but she lacks the financial means for it. She has requested this credit as she trusts that she will be able to manage it all. Talaikul I. is a widow. She has educated her four children herself and is still providing for them as best she can. She does farming, growing various vegetables, and at this moment she is really hoping to obtain this loan, which will allow her to purchase diesel fuel.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase 150 liters [of diesel fuel]

loans.name: Yayani

texts.en:
Mrs. Yayani A. is from the barangay of Garang, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years-old. Yayani is married to Joel, a private driver and they are blessed with one school age child. To make a living, she is presently engaged in a RTW (ready to wear clothing) buying and selling, egg retailing and jewelry dealing business. She has done this business for the last four years and she earns approximately 24,000 PHP gross a month.

 In 2008, Yayani joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Yayani is now requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP as her fourth loan cycle which will be used to increase her capital and purchase additional stocks of RTW, eggs and jewelry. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family especially in meeting their basic needs, savings for future use especially for her child’s education and loan repayments.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Josepina

texts.en:
Mrs. Josepina K., from the barangay of San Apolinario, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, is 53 years old and now living with Cepreno Sejesmundo, a fisherman with an average daily income of P300.00. To make a living, Josepina has sold fish for 30 years, earning approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Josepina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP, her second from PMPC, which she will use to purchase additional fishing nets, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and save for future use and house improvements.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase of additional fishing nets

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Anelyn J. is 31 years old and from the barangay of San Apolinario, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is married to Artemio J., an OFW (Overseas Filipino Worker), and has three school-aged children. In the photo, she is pictured with one of her children.
To make a living, Anelyn is engaged in agricultural activity, particularly in papaya production. She has been engaged in her business for one year already and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from this activity. She also receives a monthly allowance from her husband as an OFW.
In 2008, Anelyn joined Kiva partner, PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers for papaya production. This will be her third loan from PMPC. Anelyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs and saving for future use, especially for her children’s education.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers for papaya production

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad, a resident of the mid-sized city of Riwind, Pakistan, owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 15 years. She is a mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. All of them are enrolled in school and are getting an education. To give them a good education, Irshad operates a decorative embroidery business. She makes the embroidered dresses on order. She completes each dress in two days and gets a profit of Rs. 500 on each dress. She wishes to send her children to good colleges after completing their 10th standard. 

Her husband's name is M. M.. He operates a sanitary business. He has a sanitary shop in the market and he sells taps, water pipes etc. He has 20 years of experience in this business. His earning helps him to meet the financial expenses of the family.

Irshad has successfully completed two loans from Asasah. With the loan profit, she bought a color television and a fridge. Now she is applying for the third time for a loan from Asasah to invest in her husband’s sanitary business so he can purchase sanitary supplies (taps and water pipes) in bulk and increase the profit from his business.

loans.use: To purchase the sanitary supplies in bulk to sell

loans.name: Vanessa Claire

texts.en:
Vanessa Claire L. (pictured center, with the white shirt) is 28 years old and from the barangay of Maloro, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental. She is married, and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Vanessa Claire runs a food business with one stall at the city food court and sari-sari store. She has been engaged in her business for two years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per month from this activity. 
In 2008, Vanessa Claire joined PMPC, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 PHP, part of which will be used to add to her business capital and part for the renovation of her stall. This is her seventh loan from PMPC. Vanessa Claire plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions, especially in meeting their basic needs, saving for future use, and for possible business expansion.

About PMPC
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her food business and to renovate her stall

location.town: Maloro, Tangub City, Misamis Occidental, Mindanao

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz, a resident of mid-sized city Riwind, Pakistan, owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over ten years. She is a mother of seven children: five sons and two daughters. Her eldest son works in a cotton factory, receiving a monthly wage, and the next eldest is a painter. The others are enrolled in school and read in 8th, 7th, 6th and 5th level. 

Shahnaz operates a clothes-sewing business to pay the education expenses for her children. She sews clothes for her neighbors and completes two dresses in a day, earning Pak Rs. 200 for her work. Her husband's name is M. M. and he has been involved in the dairy business for the last 10 years. He has two buffalo which produce almost 20-22kgs of milk, which he then sells in the community and also in the milk shops. His good quality milk lures customers to come to him for purchasing milk. His income helps to meet the financial expenses of the family. 

Shahnaz has successfully completed three previous loans from Asasah and has now applied for the fourth time to invest the capital in her husband’s dairy business.  He will purchase another buffalo and expand the dairy business.

loans.use: Purchase another buffalo to expand the dairy business

loans.name: Irshad Begum's Group

texts.en:
Irshad begum, a resident of mid-sized city Riwind, Pakistan, owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 10 years. She is a mother of six children: four daughters and two sons. Her eldest son has a food stand where he sells Nan and chanay, the most favorite Punjabi dish in Pakistan, to generate income for the family. The next eldest is a painter and paints doors and walls when needed. The others are enrolled in school and read in 8th, 7th and 6th level.  

A very talented lady, Irshad operates an embroidery business. She makes embroidered dresses after receiving orders from her neighbors and relatives in order to generate income. She can complete one dress in a day due to her expertise and full dedication in her work.

Irshad has successfully repaid her first loan to Asasah and has now applied for a second loan. She wants to invest the capital in her sons’ business so he can purchase material (flour, chick peas, spices and cooking oil) in bulk and increase the profitability of his food stand.

loans.use: Purchase the required material for food stand

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
Nighat is a resident of Lahore, Pakistan, an area famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. She is the wife of S. K. and the mother of two kids. Nighat is 40 years old and is a very caring lady. She owns a house of four rooms and has been living in it with her family for over twenty years. She and her daughter are both very active ladies, managing the household chores and cooking food for the family on time.  

Her husband and one of her sons are motor mechanics, together operating a motor workshop where they repair every type of vehicle. They have obtained a good reputation among their customers and have been doing this work for over ten years.  

Nighat has successfully completed two loans to Asasah and has now applied for the third time. She wants to invest the capital in her husband’s workshop so he can purchase the repairing tools necessary to expand his motor workshop. This will enable her husband and son to better serve their customers and generate good profit.

loans.use: Purchase repairing tools for motor workshop

loans.name: Mrs. Saran Boeun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 11 people from Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province. Mrs. Saran B. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. The group members will use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Saran B. is a farmer who owns a two-hectare piece of land to grow crops to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field is ready to plow but she does not have enough money to support it. Therefore, to improve production, Mrs. Saran B. is asking for a loan to hire a plowing machine to plow her field. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is a farming laborer, while the others attend a local public school.

loans.use: To hire a plowing machine to plow her field

loans.name: John

texts.en:
In the small town of Katikara in Uganda lives a gentle man called John. He is the father of six and operates a motorcycle spare parts shop. He is aged 37 years and is the breadwinner for his family in terms of their welfare and paying school fees for his children. He dreams of educating them to university level so that they can be independent and responsible citizens.

John first operated a produce business in which he would buy and sell dry foods but later left it to start the spare parts shop for motorcycles which has now operated for six years. This is his third loan from HOFOKAM and he intends to purchase motorcycle tires and oil to sell.

loans.use: To purchase motorcycle tires and oil to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Phang Vorn Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of eleven people living in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province. Mrs. Phang V. is the village bank president, selected by all the members who will use the loan for different purposes. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Chorn Mouv, is a farmer who owns a half-hectare of land to grow crops to support his family. The problem is that the field has infertile soil and is far away from any irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Phang V. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is the mother of eight children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a laborer, and the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Zubaida's Group

texts.en:
Zubaida, a resident of Lahore, Pakistan, famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. She is a widow and the mother of four sons. Her elder son has a food stand in the main market. Her second son operates a utensils selling business. The other two sons are drivers and operate rickshaws (local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

She is a very practical lady. After the death of her husband, she made herself strong and took care of her sons, helping to establish them in their businesses by working as a  seamstress.  She has been doing this work for over twenty years. Now her sons want her to rest. The family is very happy and supportive for each other. 

Zubaida has successfully repaid three loans to Asasah and is now applying for the fourth time to invest capital in her elder son’s business so that he can purchase spices, rice, lentils and cooking oi to expand his food stand.

loans.use: Purchase additional supplies of food for his food stand

loans.name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en: Human life is full of unhappy occasions and events. Not everything goes smoothly and happens the way we want it. However, life itself is a great source of relaxation for people who possess imagination and creativity. Nobody is obliged to suffer and be an outsider. Anarkul T., the leader of this group, had faced quite a big ordeal when she divorced her husband as she still had to provide a living for her two children and her daughter was very little at that moment. However, Anarkul decided to accept things as they were and just keep going. Five years ago, right after her divorce, she made a decision to come to the capital and she started her own business. It was not that easy since she had a little child to take care of. She remembered her old skill of making traditional blankets and pillows. She started selling blankets, pillows and other hand made articles, and over the past years she has managed to provide for herself a stable income. She has big plans of opening a factory to produce blankets and pillows. She believes that this factory would at least provide some women with jobs. Now Anarkul needs this loan to invest money in producing blankets and pillows, to purchase wadding and for quilting. Anarkul’s partners: Meerim I., 29, is married and has a son. Her husband works as a policeman. Meerim works for the net marketing company Oriflame. Meerim and her husband need a loan to buy two calves to raise. Anara B., 54, is a mother of three children. She sells detergents and soft drinks and manages to earn around $200. Her husband is a farmer. Their children help Anara work in a shop. Anara hopes to obtain this loan and invest it in increasing the turnover and assortment of goods for sale. Darika K., 47, is a widow. She is the mother of three children. Her son works as a salesman and helps Darika to provide for the family. Darika sells different kinds of consumer’s goods. Now she needs a loan to purchase paints and make some repairs at home. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy materials needed for production

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
She is a businesswoman in Hoima, Uganda, operating a retail shop and has been in business for ten years. She says it’s a profitable one because it has maintained her and the family of four people.

Her name is Joyce. She is married to a driver and has three children, a family with which she lives in a rented house. She says she would like to shift her business premises from the village to the main town where there are bigger clientele numbers.

This is Joyce’s second loan, intended to enable her to purchase sugar, posho (maize flour) and cooking oil to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, posho and cooking oil for her shop

loans.name: Rukshana's Group

texts.en:
Rukshana, a resident of Lahore (which is famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods) is the wife of A. M. and the mother of four kids: two sons and two daughters. None of her kids go to school to get an education.

A very talented lady, Rukhsana operates a business sewing clothes. She sews clothes by receiving orders from her neighbors. By seeing her steadily progress, her relatives have started giving her orders, too. Now she charges them between 100 and 150 PKR for each dress. Her income has become the major source for her family because her husband’s income is insufficient to meet their financial expenses.

Rukhsana is applying for a loan for the third time from Asasah.  She will invest the capital in her business so she can purchase an electric sewing machine and sew more clothes in a day and increases her income.

loans.use: Purchase an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes

loans.name: Emerthe

texts.en:
Emerthe is 54 years old and is married with two children. She is well-known in the business of selling bananas and she has been in this business for about fifteen years. She runs her business from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day.

Emerthe would like to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase a large quantity of bananas. With this additional quantity for sale, she will hopefully earn more profits. This, in turn, will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and set up some new sources of income as well as create more jobs for the people in her community.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of bananas to sell

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is a produce dealer operating his business from Katikara, Uganda. Besides selling produce, he and his wife are peasant farmers. He is the breadwinner for his family of seven people and has been dealing in produce for the last twenty years. His wish for his family is to educate his children up to university level.

Justus, however, says his produce business is affected some times when prices for the maize he sells fall and he fails to get the profit margin he wishes. This is his second loan from HOFOKAM and the purpose of the loan is to buy more maize to sell.

loans.use: To buy more maize to sell

loans.name: Naila's Group

texts.en:
Naila, a resident of Lahore (which is famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods) is the wife of S. B. and the mother of two sons. She wants to raise them with a good education, so this resulted in them both being enrolled in a school.  The elder son reads in 5th standard (grade) and the younger on is in 2nd standard. Although she is not educated, she knows the value of education, so she also enrolled them in a tuition center so they get more attention from a teacher and can concentrate on their studies.

A very caring and talented lady, Naila operates a business selling clothes. She purchases the clothes from different cities (Peshawar, Faisalabad and Multan) because of good quality and cheap rates. She has six years of experience in this business. She does this work to give a better future to her kids.

Her husband operates a scrap business in the community which he has been handling for the last seven years. He also does a government job in the morning for meager income. They both work hard to manage their finances and to give a good future to their kids.

Naila has completed her two loans from Asasah and now is applying for the third time to invest the capital in her clothing business so she can purchase the clothes in bulk and increases the profit from it.

loans.use: Purchase clothes in bulk to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Seam Sok Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Seam S. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members living in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province. This village bank loan has eleven people, who will each use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Seam S. and her husband, Mr. Sophany Lak, are farmers who own 1.5-hectares of land to grow crops to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their field has infertile soil and is far away from any irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Seam S. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is the mother of five children, four of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the youngest one is one year old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Gorretti

texts.en:
Gorretti is a 30-year-old lady living in Katikara,Uganda. She is married to a high school teacher and together they have three children.

Gorretti is a qualified teacher and she operates a stationery shop. She is now out of the teaching business so as to be able to look after her young twins aged three years as she operates her stationery shop.

Gorretti wants to expand the business opportunities of her stationery shop by adding a photocopier, some computers so as to also offer secretarial services and, in the process, have an all-round station for secretarial and stationery needs.

Gorretti got to know about HOFOKAM through a friend who advised her to inject additional capital into her shop to progress to the next level. She intends to use the loan to buy books, pencils, pens, rulers, printing paper and other items to add to her stationery services shop.

loans.use: To buy books, pencils, pens, rulers and printing paper to sell in her shop

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen is a resident of Lahore (famous for its historical places and its Punjabi foods) in Pakistan. She is the mother of five children: three sons and two daughters. She owns a house of four rooms and has been living in it with her family for over 15 years. Her first two sons are painters and paint windows and doors on call. Her youngest son is a motor mechanic. Her elder daughter reads at the 7th standard and her younger daughter at the 4th standard.

A very talented and hard-working lady, Parveen manages the household chores and operates her clothes-selling business as well. She purchases clothes from different cities (Peshawar, Multan and Faisalabad) and sells to her community and to relatives as well. Her income helps her to save money for her children's marriages.

Parveen is applying for a loan for the second time from Asasah, to invest the capital in her clothes-selling business so she can purchase more clothes and increase the profit by selling to more customers. Note: “She has no available stock of clothes to show in the picture”.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Srey Me Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Srey M. is the village bank president of a group loan consisting of ten people who live in Peam Reang Leu village in Kandal province. She was selected by all the members who will use the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Morn Bork, are farmers who own 3.5-hectares of land to grow crops to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their corn field is ready to be planted but they do not have enough money to get it done. So to improve production, Mrs. Srey M. is applying for a loan to hire farm laborers. Mrs. Srey M. is the mother of five children, three of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others attend the local public school.

loans.use: To hire farm laborers to grow corn

loans.name: Jalia

texts.en: Jalia is married to a taxi driver. She has six children and all her children go to school.  Jalia takes care of additional family members. Jalia rents a shop where she sells second hand clothes.  She has been in this clothing business for a very long time and she is proud of it. She incurs transport costs to and from buying second hand clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Jalia uses public transport to and from shopping and goes shopping once a week.  Jalia wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. Her major customers are mainly women and young girls. Besides this clothing business, she also owns rental rooms. Jalia works six days week. Her business challenges are transportation and the ever-increasing prices of second clothes. Her goals and aspirations include going directly to import her clothes and educating her children up to the university. Jalia decided to work with MCDT because it was near her home and was charging low interest rates. Jalia has been with MCDT for 10 years. She resides in and rents a four-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Bech

texts.en: Mr. Bech B. is a villager in Preaek Svay village in Kandal province and he is 44 years old. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice to sell to support his family. He is a fisherman too. His problem is that his field has infertile soil and it is far away from the irrigation system. So to improve production, Mr. Bech B. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. His wife, Mrs. Khieng Say, is a chef. He is the father of four children. All of the children are studying in the local public school. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Damascene

texts.en:
Damascene is 34 years old and is married with one child. He struggles by selling a variety of drinks and this is his third successful year in this business. His pub is open from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day.

Damascene is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business through adding a variety of drinks in his pub and some food supplies. With these additional goods for sale, he will hopefully earn more profits and these profits will be used for further reinvestment and for building a secure future for his small family.

loans.use: To buy a variety of drinks for his pub including water, soda and beer

loans.name: Helen Angcap's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Helen A., 40 years of age, is a widow who resides in Bintana, Tangub City. Helen is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group members receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Helen A.’s Group.
	
Helen was blessed with two children who are now school age. For her living, she decided to engage in operating a sari-sari store and a banana buy and sell business. For four years, she has been able to maintain the businesses during ups and downs. Now she earns an average net income of not less than P 3,500 a month, which is very helpful to her family.  She joined the cooperative in 2009. As an active center chief and member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting an amount of P5,000 as her second loan t to add capital to her existing sari-sari store and banana buy and sell business. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family, to meet their basic needs and save for future use. She is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive. 

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her existing businesses

loans.name: Erlinda Bergado's Group

texts.en:
Erlinda B. (left), 58 years of age and married, is a resident of Dimalco, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. Erlinda is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Erlinda B.’s Group. 	
Erlinda is married to Remegio, 63 years old and a farmer. They are blessed with 13 children; 11 are now adults and two are now school age. To help her husband, she decided to operate a retail store. For six years, she has been able to maintain the business. She is earning an average net income of not less than P 3,500 a month, which is very helpful to their family income.  She joined the cooperative in the year 2009. As an active member of the PDP-LP Program of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting  P 5,000.00 as her second loan to add capital to her existing sari-sari store business. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of her family, to meet their basic needs and savings for future use. She is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive. 

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing sari-sari store business

loans.name: Bopha

texts.en: Mrs. Bopha A. is living in Chong Preaek village in Kandal province and she was born in 1968. She is a housewife and her husband, Mr. Saren Chan, is a motorbike taxi driver. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. So to improve their family living conditions, Mrs. Bopha A. is asking for a loan to buy a cart to transport bread to sell. This is a new business. She is the mother of three children. One of the children is a construction worker, one is a rice seller, and one attends the local public school. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy a cart to transport bread to sell

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en: Zaituni is married with four children and all her children go to school.  Zaituni takes care of additional family members. She works and lives in Kisaasi Kulambiro Zone, Kawempe Division, in Kampala District. She changed her business from food vending to charcoal selling. Currently, Zaituni owns a store at her home where she sells charcoal. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She has been in this charcoal business for just a few months. Besides this charcoal business, she owns rooms to rent, which brings in some income. Her major customers are her neighbors. Zaituni works seven days a week. Her business challenges include defaulters and seasonality. Zaituni aspires to go directly to the villages for charcoal. She  joined MCDT because of their timely loans. She lives in and owns a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bgas of charcoal

loans.name: Sak

texts.en: Mrs. Sak N. is living in Preak Ta Ong Ti Bei village in Kandal province and she is 63 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Thav Chhiek, are mango sellers in the local market. Since their business is going well, they want to expand it. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sak N. is asking for a loan to buy more mangoes to resell.  With this business, they support two children. One of her children is helping the parents and the other is a jeweler. Her husband is in the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes to resell

loans.name: Viviana

texts.en:
Mrs. Viviana R. is from Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 54 years old and married with only one child. To make a living, she manages her sari-sari store and her husband is a farmer. She has been managing her business for more than two years and earns approximately 4,500 a month. Her husband also supports their daily basic needs.

She joined PMPC to gain access to financial support and to engage in other business activities. She successfully repaid her previous loan of 4,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used for the expansion of her business. Now she has a new loan of 5,000 from PMPC, which will be used for additional capital of her business. She plans that the additional revenue generated from the business will help to improve the background of the borrower's family.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Pon

texts.en: Mr. Pon K. was born in 1948 and he lives in Chrouy Chrey village in Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Orim Yat, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow crops to sell to support their family. Their problem is that their field has infertile soil and it has a lot of insects. So to improve production, Mr. Pon K. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. He is the father of a child who is a farmer too. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Nat

texts.en: Mr. Nat N. is living in Choeng Prey village in Kandal province and he is 44 years old. He is a duck breeder who earns some money from selling duck eggs to support his family. His problem is that his ducks are too small to sell and he does not have enough money to buy more feed. So to solve this condition, Mr. Nat N. is applying for a loan to buy duck food and a cow for breeding to start a new business. His wife, Mrs. Orieng Poum, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for her family. Through this activity, they support six children. One of the children is a seamstress in a garment factory and the others are attending the local public school. His wife is in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy duck food and a cow for breeding

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chy

texts.en: Mr. Chy C. is a villager in Taok Ma village in Kandal province and he is 40 years old. He and his wife, Mrs. Kha Sok, are farmers who rent a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. So to improve their family's living conditions, they want to start a new business but they do not have enough money. Thus, Mr. Chy C. is applying for a loan to buy two cows for breeding. He is a father of six children. Two of the children are seamstresses in a garment factory, three of the children are attending the local public school, and one is too young to work or study. His wife appears in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding

loans.name: Boutsomé

texts.en:
Madame Boutsomé A. is 43 years old. She's been selling fish from her home for the past two years. Boutsomé is married and has four children. Her husband is also a salesman of sorts. 

Boutsomé purchases her merchandise from Ghana. She is requesting a loan of 400,000 CFA to purchase 25 cartons of frozen fish. This will be her third loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase frozen fish

loans.name: Simon

texts.en: Simon is a Nairobi-based businessman. He sells stationery, cartridges and printers and he employs one person. He has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to increase his stock of printers and printing sets. This loan has been guaranteed by his group members. Married with one child who is in school, Simon hopes to prosper and to provide a quality life and education for his family. Simon describes himself as perfect.

loans.use: To increase his stock of printers and printing sets

loans.name: Evalyne

texts.en:
Evalyne is a 41-year-old lady. She is a widow and the mother of two who are aged 23 and 4 years. She sells used clothes such as boys' tracksuits in Nairobi. She has been in this business for five years and employs two people. She describes her business as busy and hopes to grow her business to a larger scale. 

Evalyne has requested a loan of Kes. 30,000 to increase her stock of boys' tracksuits and to introduce ladies' tracksuits for sale in her business. She hopes to create jobs for many jobless youth and describes herself as humble and friendly.

loans.use: To increase her stock of boys' tracksuits and to introduce ladies' tracksuits

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud is a 33-year-old businessman. He sells used clothes especially ladies' wear in Nairobi. He has been in this business for six years and terms it competitive. His customers are mainly ladies and he employs one person.

Eliud has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to increase his stock of ladies' clothes for sale. He hopes to diversify into other businesses and to own a supermarket in the future. In five years, he plans to have bought a house, employed more people and have children. He describes himself as hard-working.

loans.use: To increase his stock of ladies' clothes

loans.name: Erke's Group

texts.en:
Erke D. is the leader of a loan group.  She is 44, married and has four sons and a daughter. Two older sons work in Bishkek. They sell building materials on the market. The other children study at school. Erke with her husband have a farm where they raise cattle and grow different fruits and vegetables. They have been farming since 1994. With the money received from this loan Erke will purchase 200 liters of fuel, which is needed during the sowing process. In the future she plans for her older sons to marry and to improve the family's living conditions. 

Gulmira K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 43 and married with three daughters and a son. The second daughter is married. The other children are students. In order to make money Gulmira sells traditional cloth and dressmaking supplies. She wants to get a loan to purchase 200 liters of fuel and potato seeds.

Zhumamidin Z. is 48 and a widow. He has two daughters and a son. The older daughter and son are married. The younger daughter works in Bishkek.  Zhumamidin himself works as a driver. He also has one hectare of land, which he wants to sow. With money received from the loan he will buy fuel which he needs during the sowing process.

Damira K. is 41and  married. She has three sons and a daughter. All of them are students. Damira's husband has been reselling cattle for fourteen years.  His initial investment in this business activity was 10000 soms (218.34$). Now he earns 15000 soms (327.51$) a month. This profit made it possible for them to purchase a house. Damira wants to get a loan to purchase cattle in order to increase his herd.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel for farming

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is 37 years old. He is married and a father to two children aged 15 and 6 years. He owns a mobile phone repair business in Nairobi. He has requested for a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy mobile phone spare parts. This loan is guaranteed by his group members. He plans to expand his business and open more outlets. He describes himself as visionary.

loans.use: To buy mobile phone spare parts

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a 32 year old business lady. She runs a salon in Nairobi where she offers beauty services such as manicures, pedicure, facials and hair care services. She has been in this business for the last eight years and sees it as a having good business potential. She has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy a barber seat and a wall dryer. 

Jackline is single and desires to prosper at her business. She would like to open other outlets in different places. She describes herself as a good person..

loans.use: To buy a barber seat and a wall dryer

loans.name: Arcelita

texts.en:
49-year-old Arcelita R. has proven her reproductive role as a woman. She gave birth to five loving children from her husband Ricardo. All throughout her 25 years of motherhood and 26 years of married life, she has had no other intention but to help her husband support the needs of their children and provide them with a life that is enjoyable and worth living. Therefore, in 2004 she took the opportunity to enhance her capability to becoming productive. She joined ASHI and the loan she has able to avail was her means to establishing her own livelihood, which is hog/pig fattening and/or breeding. The piglets are fattened and some will be sold. Her fattened hogs are sold to market and to people in their village either slaughtered or alive after four months. 

Arcelita and her family enjoy the profit her business is gaining. It is a huge help to augment her husband’s small amount of honorarium for being the village councilor. Through her membership in ASHI, by maintaining a very good performance in terms of repayment, and attendance at ASHI weekly center meeting, Arcelita wishes to take more loans to be able to have the opportunity to grow her business and earn more profit. This will be her means to support the needs of her four children who have stopped studying, though she still hopes that they will decide to go back to school and finish their studies until college just like her eldest child.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, feed and vaccine

loans.name: Alberata

texts.pt:
A cliente nasceu em Maputo, aos 01 de Outubro de 1983. Estudou ate 12 classe e parou devido a dificuldades financeiras. Vive com o esposo que e policia. Tem dois filhos,envia a mesada para os pais pois vivem com os filhos da cliente em causa. Passou a sua infancia no Bairro de Chamanculo onde se conheceu com o seu marido, casaram e mudaram-se para o Bairro de Nkobe no Municipio da Matola a dois anos e vivem numa casa propria.

A cliente trabalha na Escola Primaria Completa de Chamissava, com a categoria professional de docente auferindo o salario mensal de 5.699,00(cinco mil seiscentos noventa e nove meticais). Este e o primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku, nunca teve emprestimo em nenhum Banco.  Teve o conhecimento dos servicos da Hluvuku atraves dum colega de servico na Escola Primaria complete de Chamissava que tambem e cliente  desta instituicao. Pretende solicitar mais  emprestimos na Hluvuku.

Com este valor pretende comecar coma sua obra no Bairro onde reside, no que sae na foto ela e o seu marido. Tem como desafio ver sua obra concluida e o seu maior sonho e de adquirir uma viatura, pois, da casa da cliente para a paragem, terminal de Nkobe sao cerca de 4km. E mesmo chegando a paragem ha dificuldades de transporte.
texts.en:
Alberata was born in Maputo on October 1st, 1983. She studied until 12th grade and had to stop due to financial difficulties. She lives with her husband who is a policeman. They have two children, and she send money to her parents. She spent her childhood in the district of Chamanculo where she met her husband. They got married and moved to Nkobe district in Matola two years ago, and live in their own house. Alberata works at the Chamissava Elementary School as a teacher, and makes U$164 per month. This is her first loan with Hluvuku, and she's never had a loan with any other bank. She heard of Hluvuku from a workmate who's a client. She intends to start building her house in the neighborhood she lives with her husband, pictured with her. Her biggest dream is to finish that construction and later on buy a car, because it's 4km from her house to the closest bus station.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction supplies

loans.name: God Power Group

texts.en:
Philimena V. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Power.  She is 38 years old, single, and has four children who range from six to 25 years old. She was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to poverty.

For eight years, she has been selling used clothes on Front Street in downtown Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner that keeps her customers returning.  

She plans to use her 16,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 51,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes.  Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Philimena is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 30 years old and is married with one five-year-old child who is in school.

James runs a business selling clothes in Nairobi where he sells ladies’ used clothes. He has been in this business for five years and he refers to his business environment as conducive. He employs one person and desires to grow his business and start importing clothes.

James has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 to add to his stock of ladies’ clothes. In Faulu Kenya, he has learnt and developed a savings culture. He describes himself as hardworking and committed.

loans.use: To add to his stock of ladies' clothes

loans.name: Ana

texts.pt:
Ana E. nasceu em Morrumbene, Provincia de Inhambane, aos 09 de Janeiro de 1953. Estudou ate oitava classe e deixou quando os pais lhe obrigaram a casar com o seu primeiro marido, quando esta ainda era adolescente. E depois casou-se pela segunda vez e divorciou, vive com as sua duas filhas de 24 e 25 anos de idade e sao estudantes. Apois ter  divorciado foi construir a sua casa no Bairro 25 de Junho onde reside ate este momento. Trabalha como costureira e tambem tem uma barraca de produtos alimentarios. Aprendeu a costurar com o seu pai desde 1997. Para alem das filhas vivem tambem com uma neta.

No seu negocio o produto com maior saida sao os uniformes escolar apesar de serem sasonais, isto e, no inicio do ano lectivo.  Onde com um rolo de tecido  adquirido por 780 mt chega a produzir camisas no valor de 1800 mt. na barraca consegue ter rendimento de 3000 mt/mes, sobre tudo quando trata-se de finais de semana do final do mes.
E primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku, e nunca trabalhou com nenhum outro banco. Teve o conhecimento dos services da Hluvuku atraves duma amiga, que e cliente da Instituicao.

Com este valor pretende comprar tecidos, aumentar os produtos da sua barraca e melhora as condicoes da casa. Tem como desafio diversificar os produtos vendendo carnes e petiscos. O seu sonho e abrir mais empreendimentos nos outros bairros.
texts.en:
Ana E. was born in Morruembene, Inhambane Province, on January 9, 1953. He finished 8th grade but had to drop school when her parents forced her to marry her first husband, when she was only a teenager. She later married again and got divorced. She lives with her two daughters who are 24 and 25, both students, and a granddaughter. After her divorce she started building the house they reside now. She works as a seamstress and also has a tent from where she sells food products. She learned to sew with her father. Her biggest selling products are school uniforms, but that's seasonal (she only sells them in the beginning of the year). With her food stand she's able to make around U$86 per month, especially on weekends and at the end of the month. This is Ana's first loan with Hluvuku, and she has never worked with any other bank. She heard of the institution from a friend who's also a client. With her loan, she hopes to buy more fabric, and also improve the variety of products offered in her tent. She would like to eventually sell meat cuts and snacks. Her dream is to open more stores in other neighborhoods.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fabric for sewing, Food products for reselling

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is married to a business lady and they have three children.

Stephen is a 26-year-old manufacturer. He manufactures slabs and ventilation windows and sells them to people who are building, to hardware stores and to contractors. He also does welding to earn extra income. He has been in this business for the last six years.

Stephen has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to purchase a machine for producing slabs. He hopes to increase his slab production and own a wholesale shop for selling slabs and ventilation windows. He describes himself as focused.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for producing slabs

loans.name: Maria

texts.pt:
Maria M. C. M. nasceu em Maputo, aos 26 de Abril de 1970. Esta a fazer 1 ano de Direito na Universidade Eduardo Mondlane. Vive com os seus 02 filhos de 05 e 20 anos de idade e estudam. E solteira  vive numa casa propria.

A cliente trabalha na Procuradoria Da Republica da Cidade de Maputo, com a categoria professional de escrituraria Judicial Provincial, auferindo um  salario mensal de 8.301,50(oito mil trezentos e um meticais e cinquenta centavos).
  
Este e o primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku, ja teve outro emprestimo no BCI para iniciar a obra no valor de 50.000,00 Mt.  Teve o conhecimento dos servicos da Hluvuku atraves duma prima de nome Adelaide cliente  desta instituicao, concretamente em Boane. Pretende solicitar mais  emprestimos na Hluvuku.

Com este valor pretende fazer o reboco da casa e cobertura da Mercearia no Bairro onde reside. Tem como desafio ver sua obra concluida e o seu maior sonho e de colocar a sua Mercearia em funcionamento. Ela veu pedir o emprestimo em pessoa mais quando nos for tirar foto, ela nao estava disponivel, entao na foto esta o seu filho maior, de 20 anos.
texts.en:
Maria M. C. M. was born in Maputo on April 26, 1970. She is going to law school at the Eduardo Mondlane University in Maputo. She lives with her two children who are 5 and 20, both also students. She's single and lives in her own house. Maria works in the city's justice department and makes around U$240 per month. This is her first loan with Hluvuku but she's had a loan with BCI bank before to build her house. She heard of Hluvuku from a cousin called Adelaide, who's also a client of the institution in the city of Boane. She hopes to fix her house and start a business. In the picture is her 20 year old son since she was not available at the time.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction supplies

loans.name: Pedro

texts.pt:
Pedro A. V. nasceu em Morrumbene, Provincia de Inhambane, aos 15 de Julho de 1960. Estudou ate decima segunda classe. Vive com a esposa e os seus tres filhos de idades comprendidas entre 02.12 e 13 anos. Tem dois filhos a estudarem. Nao sustenta mais ninguem. Passou a sua infancia na Catembe, e vive no Municipio da Matola concretamente no Bairro de ndlavela a 15 anos, numa casa propria. O cliente trabalha na SERVICOM, LDA, com a categoria professional de Guarda Livros desde 01 deJunho de 1994 em regime de contrato efectivo e aufere o salario mensal de 13.000,00(treze mil meticais).  

Este e o primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku e ja teve um emprestimo no Bim num valor de 50.000,00(cinquenta mil meticais) que aplicou na construcao de uma Mercearia que se encontra num mercadinho enfrente a sua casa.  Teve o conhecimento dos services da Hluvuku atraves do irmao de nome  Joaquim Vilanculos que tambem e cliente  desta instituicao. Pretende solicitar mais  emprestimos na Hluvuku.

Com este valor pretende dar continuidade coma sua obra no Bairro de kongolote. Tem como desafio ver sua obra concluida e o seu maior sonho e abertura de novos estabelecimentos de negocio em Kongolote.
texts.en:
Pedro A. V. was born in Morrumbene, Inhambane Province on July 15, 1960. He finished twelfth grade in school. He lives with his wife and their three children, who are 2, 12 and 13 years old. Two of the children go to school. He does not support anyone else. Pedro spent his childhood in Catembe, and for fifteen years he has been living in his own house in the City of Matola, Ndlavela neighborhood. He has worked for Servicom, LDA as a bookkeeper since June 1, 1994. He works under contract and receives a monthly salary of 13,000 meticais. This is Pedro's first loan from Hluvuku. He has had another loan from Bim (Millenium Bim Bank) for 50,000 meticais, which he used to build a grocery store which is located in a small market in front of his house. He learned about Hluvuku's services through his brother, Joaquim Vilanculos, who is also a customer at this institution. He intends to ask Hluvuku for other loans. He intends to use this loan to continue building his house in Kongolote neighborhood. His challenge is to finish his house, and his greatest dream is to open new business establishments in Kongolote.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cement, zinc sheets, sand, stone, etc.

loans.name: C5259 Abahuje Group

texts.en:
Dancilla is the leader of this group which is called Abahuje in the local language. The group contains five members: most of them are women and only one is a man. Each member in this group has his own business. They are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses.

Dancilla is 41 years old and is married with four children aged between 6 and 18. She is representative of the group and sells foodstuffs to her neighbors. This is the 3rd successful year she has been in operation; her business is open from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Dancilla will use her loan to add a large quantity of foodstuffs to her small shop. With this loan she will be able to save money for the future and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To add a large quantity of foodstuffs to her small shop

loans.name: Jean Marie Vianey

texts.en:
Jean Marie Vianey (JMV) is 34 years old and is married with three children who are aged between 1 and 7. He also takes care of one dependent relative. He works hard for the development of his family.

JMV owns a small shop which sells various styles of clothes and this is his tenth year of successful operation. He employs four people from his community as helpers so that his business runs well. His daily activities run from 6 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day except Saturday.

JMV is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of growing his business. He plans to add some equipment like a sewing machine to be used in sewing clothes. This loan will be very important for him because it will allow him to attract more customers. This will help him to earn more profits.

With the extra money, JMV hopes to get ahead with his family.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine to be used to sew clothes

loans.name: C5261Dufatanye Group

texts.en:
Rose is a 25-year-old married mother with one child who is four years old. Rose describes herself as a hardworking woman. Rose's business is well organized and she employs one person in her small shop selling various products. Her business is open from 7 in the morning to 5 in the evening every day except Saturday. She has engaged in this business because it is profitable in her region. This is her sixth year of successful business operation. 


Rose is the group leader. This group is called "Dufatanye" in the local language. The group includes six members; each one has their own business. Some of the businesses are a spare parts business, selling cakes and selling various products, etc. Rose and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand their businesses so that they offer a good service for their customers. This loan will impact the group members by helping them to purchase larger quantities which will allow them to earn more profits. With extra money, Rose and her group hope to save and to reinvest in their businesses.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en: Agatha is married to builder and they have one child. Her child goes to school. Agatha takes care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Makerere University selling biscuits, sweets, children’s reading charts, envelopes and cigarettes. She wants to use this loan to buy more biscuits, reading charts, envelopes and boxes of cigarettes. Besides owning a stall in Makerere University, she also acts as a cleaner in Mary Stuart Hall.  Her major customers are students of Makerere University. Agatha works six days a week. Her major business challenge is the seasonality, mainly when students break off for holidays.  She aspires to live a better life.  Agatha joined MCDT because it was near her place of work and residence. She lives in and rents a two-room house where she stays with five people. The family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more biscuits, reading charts, cigarettes and envelopes

loans.name: Jappo Liggey Asf N°5 Group

texts.fr:
Jappo Ligguey (asf)  est une association mixte composée de plusieurs personnes microentrepreuneuses. Elle a été créée en 2009 par un groupe de femmes pour  rassembler  tous leurs  paires  du  quartier  Angle Serigne Fallou  (asf) autour d’un même idéal  « l’entraide  pour travailler ». Elle est dirigée par Madame Marie Ndiaye Diouf et  est scindée en plusieurs sous groupes de 5 sous l’influence de l’agent de crédit de la caisse Moda Kane pour  que tous  les membres  puissent  bénéficier mieux des services d’U-IMCEC. C’est ainsi que certains sous groupes ont déposé leur demande de crédit de 500 000 FCFA qu’ils vont se partager en part égale. 
Quant au  sous Jappo Liggey asf n°5, elle est gérée par la présidente Madame Saly S.. C’est une femme mariée qui s’active dans le commerce du couscous qu'elle prépare elle-même depuis 2006. Elle compte avec sa part du prêt, ses 100 000 FCFA,  renforcer son activité en approvisionnant en matières premières pour le couscous. Elle veut acheter du mil, maïs, arachide etc . Ainsi ce prêt va lui permettre de renouveler ses stocks afin de mieux tirer profit de son business.
Pour les autres membres du sous groupe, ce prêt leurs permet de renforcer leurs activités. Elles sont entre autres :
 La trésorière Madame Fatma Koné s’active dans le  commerce de la friperire depuis 2 ans. 
Madame Khady M. vendeuse de prêts à porter au marché central de Thiès depuis 2 ans.
 Madame Magatte M.  qui vend du petit déjeuner et diner dans la devanture de sa maison, il y'a tout juste 1 an.Et Madame Fatou M. qui gère depuis 5 ans sa boutique d'alimentation générale

loans.use: Get supplies of various goods

loans.name: C5262 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Esperence is 48 years old, with six children aged between 4 and 28. She owns a small shop which sells various products. She is well known in the region with her business which is the reason why she is the group leader of this group which is called Twitezimbere in the local language.

This group contains six people, most of whom are women except one who is a man. Each one in group has his own business.

Esperence is in the business of selling various products such as rice, sugar, cosmetics products, and so on and she has an experience of six years. She describes herself as a hardworking woman. Her business is open from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day except Saturday.

Esperence and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products for their business. Esperence especially needs this loan in order to expand her business through purchasing more products for her shop which will allow her to satisfy the demands of her customers.

If this satisfaction is reached, Esperence hopes to earn more profits. With these profits she expects to save money for her future and pay school fees for her children as most of them are in school.

loans.use: To purchase more products for her shop to expand her business

loans.name: Hasfa

texts.en: Hasfa is widowed with seven children and four of her children are in school.  She also takes care of four grandchildren whose parents died.  Hasfa owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling second hand clothes.  She sells to all categories of people. She wants to use this loan of 200,000/= to buy additional clothes. She has been in this business for over 10 years selling at retail and wholesale. She uses public transport to and from buying second hand clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. Besides this clothing business, she is a hairdresser at her very own stall.  She pays monthly market dues of 25,000/=.  Hasfa works six days a week. Her business challenges include the ever-increasing prices of second hand clothes and transportation of clothes from Owino market to her place of business. She aspires to improve her standard of living and to educate her children up to the university.  She joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her business. Hasfa lives in a three-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy additional second hand clothes

loans.name: Alkham

texts.en:
Alkham is a farmer who lives with his family, including his wife and five children. His wife and elder son help him with caring for their land. In the past, Alkham has had problems with harvesting, and also having to sell his crop in advance and therefore seeing reduced earnings.
Now, Alkham has gained a lot of experience in his business and today his crop is one of the most demanded at the market. He now faces a small problem because his field is infertile, which makes it difficult to grow his crop. To solve this problem, Alkham has decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers to support the field and make his crop more productive.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Haidar

texts.en:
I. Haidar is 55 years old, married, and has three children. He has been running his business selling combustive-lubricating materials, such as benzene, diesel and others, for more than 14 years. Haidar's elder son helps him in the business. His current business is profitable and has allowed him to support his family for all these years. Now Haidar is planning to expand his business and increase his stock of combustive-lubricating materials for resale. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting a loan of $2000 USD. Haidar promises to repay his loan promptly and thanks everyone for supporting him.

More about Tajikistan

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase combustive-lubricating materials wholesale

loans.name: Ibrohimjon

texts.en:
I. Ibrohimjon is 22 years old. He lacked the ability to pay university fees, so Ibrohimjon was only able to finish school. After finishing school, he learned various skills, including car repair. Initially, he worked as an assistant and in time he became experienced at repairing cars. Thanks to his abilities, he was able to build his own workshop near his house where he provides his services. Now he is feeling the effects of a lack of tools and spare parts for car repair, and for that reason he is requesting a loan of $1,500 USD. Ibrohimjon is very grateful to everyone who is helping him achieve his dreams with this loan.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase tools and spare parts for car repair

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John B. is married and has four children. He has received senior high education. His wife is a trader.

John produces herbal soap for sale at Takoradi and uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. He will use the loan to buy more ingredients and raw materials to prepare his soap in larger quantities.

With the new earnings from his extended business, John plans to save to provide a meaningful education to his children.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients and raw materials to prepare his soap in larger quantities

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs such as cassava, potatoes, vegetables and oil.

loans.name: Kutbiddin

texts.en:
Kutbiddin is 28 years old, married, and has three children. For the last three years, he has worked as a farmer growing vegetables. This is the only thing he knows how to do and it is what he likes most. For Kutbiddin, there is nothing better than being in touch with nature and watching the crops of his labor grow year after year. In addition, Kutbiddin raises cattle. His family helps him with his business.
Now, Kutbiddin wants to borrow money to purchase seeds and fertilizer in order to grow seasonal vegetables. This is his second loan from Kiva partner, IMON International, and he promises to repay the loan without any violations. He thanks all lenders for their support.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Bibikhol

texts.en:
K. Bibikhol’s passion lies with children. A married mother of two, Bibikhol opened her business selling clothes with the goal of providing a better standard of living for her family. For the past 13 years, Bibikhol has successfully operated her business at the market. With her profits, she has not only improved the standard of living for her children, but she has been able to support her elderly parents as well.
Bibikhol has requested a loan of 12,000 TJS to restock her clothing business. An optimistic businesswoman, Bibikhol plans to use the loan to continue developing her business and supporting her family.

More about Tajikistan

It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To stock new clothing for the summer season

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en: Deborah is married to a dry cleaner and they have six children. All their children go to school. Deborah takes care of additional family members (parents). She owns a stall selling second hand shoes in Kalerwe market in Kawempe Division, one of Kampala city suburbs. She sells mainly children and women's shoes. She goes shopping twice a week and buys these shoes from Owino market in Kampala city. She uses public transport to and from shopping. Deborah wants to use this loan to buy more second hand shoes. She sells mainly at retail. Deborah has been in this business for over 13 years. She works seven days a week. Her business challenges include defaulters and competitors. She aspires to educate her children up to university. She joined MCDT to boost her business. She resides in and owns a two-room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses include food, and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more second hand shoes

loans.name: Working Group

texts.en:
Kladi K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Working Group. She is 43 years old, married, and has two children who are 21 and 26 years old. She also cares for three siblings. She could not continue her education through college.

For two years, Kladi has been running a restaurant at the Bernard Farm community, in the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She gives her customers good reception and nice manners, which keeps them returning. Kladi started selling with help from her sister.   

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more foodstuffs such as rice, meat and oil. Her goal is to expand by establishing another business, educate her children and improve the living conditions of her family. She describes herself as a nice, hard working and open-minded person.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kladi is holding the sign. Angeline is inset at the lower left because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs such as rice, meat and oil.

loans.name: Essi Gameli

texts.fr:
Cette femme est âgée de 30 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes depuis 06 ans. Elle associe à ce commerce celui de bijoux. Elle achète ses marchandises sur place à Lomé et les revend sur un étal au marché d’Assiyéyé. Présentement, elle est en rupture de stock. C’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite ce crédit de WAGES.
Comptant sur l’accroissement de son activité, elle espère mieux répondre aux besoins de scolarisation de ses 02 enfants
texts.en:
